items.article_title: When the Red Cross Broke Under the Weight of a Flood
items.text:
Everyone's talking about when the red cross broke under the weight of a flood. They're missing the real story.

President Coolidge said the Red Cross would handle it.

The Red Cross couldn't handle it.

items.article_title: How San Francisco's 1906 Earthquake Created the Template for Climate Insurance Retreat
items.text:
Captain Leonard D. Wildman watched San Francisco residents torch their own earthquake-damaged homes in April 1906. Insurance only paid if buildings burned, not if they cracked. The template was set. Climate retreat begins with fine print.

via The Docket

items.article_title: How San Francisco's 1906 Earthquake Created the Template for Climate Insurance Retreat
items.text: Hartford Fire Insurance: $7 million in reserves against $11 million in claims. Most policies excluded earthquake damage but covered fire. So residents lit matches to save themselves from ruin. The playbook for climate insurance retreat was written in ash. https://www.anchor.is/docket/issue/20/archive/article/9980 #ClimateInsurance #DisasterCapitalism

items.article_title: A Ski Resort Manager Watches the Powder Disappear
items.text:
The snowmaking guns run in mid-February. Through his office window, Wade Powder watches white plumes coat brown patches that should be buried under three feet of natural snow. Utah's snowpack: 52% of normal. The worst since records began in 1980.

via The Docket
items.compliance_detail: ✓ Quote ratio, ✓ Verbatim overlap, ✓ Attribution, ✓ Claim density
items.compliance_original: The snowmaking guns run in mid-February. Through his office window, Wade Powder watches white plumes coat brown patches that should be buried under three feet of natural snow. Utah's snowpack: 52% of normal. The worst since records began in 1980.

items.article_title: A Ski Resort Manager Watches the Powder Disappear
items.text:
Mid-February. The snowmaking guns are still running. Wade Powder stares through his office window at crews installing equipment on runs that should already be buried. Utah's snowpack sits at 52% of normal—matching the state's worst levels since 1980.

via The Docket
items.compliance_detail: ✓ Quote ratio, ✓ Verbatim overlap, ✓ Attribution, ✓ Claim density
items.compliance_original: Mid-February. The snowmaking guns are still running. Wade Powder stares through his office window at crews installing equipment on runs that should already be buried. Utah's snowpack sits at 52% of normal—matching the state's worst levels since 1980.

items.article_title: A Ski Resort Manager Watches the Powder Disappear
items.text: The crews are installing snowmaking equipment on runs that should be three feet deep by now. Wade Powder watches from his base lodge office as February stretches into what used to be peak season. 52% of normal snowpack. The worst in four decades. https://www.anchor.is/docket/issue/20/lived/article/10044 #climatechange #skiing
items.compliance_detail: ✓ Quote ratio, ✓ Verbatim overlap, ✓ Attribution, ✓ Claim density

items.article_title: When the Ground Falls as Fast as the Water Rises
items.text:
Engineers built seawalls for rising water.

Now it's a nature preserve in Galveston Bay.

via The Docket

video_script.title: The Architecture of Impossible Optimism, 2020-2030
video_script.hook:
Today I'm writing wall text for Gallery One.

The object is an air conditioning unit.
body_slides: Forty-seven units cataloged. All seized compressors.
Phoenix summers, 2024-2029. Martinez ran it until the end.
Estate donation form. Cause of death: heat stroke.
video_script.voiceover_text: Today I'm writing wall text for Gallery One. The object is an air conditioning unit. Forty-seven units cataloged. All seized compressors. Phoenix summers, 2024-2029. Martinez ran it until the end. Estate donation form. Cause of death: heat stroke. We preserve the machines that couldn't save us. That's The Docket. Follow for more stories like this.
video_script.cta:
Follow @docketclimate for more
Climate news · Adaptation · Speculation
Link in bio
video_script.voiceover_cta: That's The Docket. Follow for more stories like this.

video_script.title: When the Red Cross Broke Under the Weight of a Flood
video_script.hook:
Everyone's talking about when the red cross broke under the weight of a flood. They're missing the real story.

President Coolidge said the Red Cross would handle it.

The Red Cross couldn't handle it.
body_slides: Secretary Fieser, Red Cross headquarters, Washington. May 1927.
Before the breach: disaster meant local church basements, volunteer ladies.
After Mounds Landing: tent cities stretching past horizons.
video_script.voiceover_text: Everyone's talking about when the red cross broke under the weight of a flood. They're missing the real story. President Coolidge said the Red Cross would handle it. The Red Cross couldn't handle it. Secretary Fieser, Red Cross headquarters, Washington. May 1927. Before the breach: disaster meant local church basements, volunteer ladies. After Mounds Landing: tent cities stretching past horizons. We're still writing checks for that breach. More at The Docket. Follow to keep seeing these.
video_script.cta:
Follow @docketclimate for more
Climate news · Adaptation · Speculation
Link in bio
video_script.voiceover_cta: More at The Docket. Follow to keep seeing these.

Small town church basement with folding tables, women in long dresses serving soup from large pots, warm lamplight, community volunteers, 1920s America
Endless rows of canvas tents stretching to horizon, muddy ground, overcast sky, people in period clothing walking between tents, massive refugee camp, aerial perspective

items.article_title: Climate Models Miss Subsidence at Major Tide Gauges
items.text:
Between 58% and 100% of coastal marshes are losing elevation relative to sea level, sinking faster than 3mm yearly.

Satellite measurements reveal seven Atlantic coast tide gauges underestimate vertical land motion in IPCC projections.

Between 58% and 100% of coastal marshes are losing elevation…
…

items.article_title: Climate Models Miss Subsidence at Major Tide Gauges
items.text:
Seven Atlantic tide gauges are underestimating how fast the ground beneath them is sinking.

Salt marshes that buffer cities from hurricane storm surge are dropping below effective elevation. Between 58% and 100% are losing ground faster than sea level rises.

items.article_title: Climate Models Miss Subsidence at Major Tide Gauges
items.text: Seven tide gauges along the Atlantic coast. All missing the same thing. The land beneath them is sinking faster than climate models predicted. Salt marshes that protect cities from storm surge are dropping below effective elevation. The buffer zone is disappearing. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-023-37853-7 #subsidence #coastalscience
items.compliance_detail: ✓ Quote ratio, ✓ Verbatim overlap, ✓ Attribution, ✓ Claim density

items.article_title: Groundwater Pumping Caused Most Galveston Flooding Risk
items.text:
Everyone's talking about groundwater pumping caused most galveston flooding risk. They're missing the real story.

Aquifer compaction from gro…

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-74696-4?utm_source=bluesky&utm_medium=text&utm_campaign=issue_20&utm_content=science_news
#Flooding #WaterCrisis

items.article_title: Groundwater Pumping Caused Most Galveston Flooding Risk
items.text: Galveston's Pier 21 tide gauge has been watching the city sink since 1909. The ocean rose 15% of the way. The land fell the rest. Groundwater pumping collapsed the aquifer beneath the city, delivering 85% of the flood risk everyone blames on climate change.

items.article_title: Groundwater Pumping Caused Most Galveston Flooding Risk
items.text: The land sank while the ocean rose. Galveston extracted so much groundwater that the aquifer collapsed beneath the city. 0.7 meters of relative sea level rise since 1909. Only 15% came from actual ocean rise. The rest? The ground gave way. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-020-74696-4 #subsidence #groundwater
items.compliance_detail: ✓ Quote ratio, ✓ Verbatim overlap, ✓ Attribution, ✓ Claim density

items.article_title: Atlantic Coast Cities Sinking Faster Than Expected
items.text:
JFK Airport is sinking. Two millimeters a year. Radar satellites don't lie—half of New York's infrastructure sits on subsiding ground. Baltimore, Norfolk, same story. The satellites measured 13 years of slow-motion collapse. Critical systems built for old flood maps.

via The Docket
items.compliance_detail: ✓ Quote ratio, ✓ Verbatim overlap, ✓ Attribution, ✓ Claim density
items.compliance_original: JFK Airport is sinking. Two millimeters a year. Radar satellites don't lie—half of New York's infrastructure sits on subsiding ground. Baltimore, Norfolk, same story. The satellites measured 13 years of slow-motion collapse. Critical systems built for old flood maps.

items.article_title: Atlantic Coast Cities Sinking Faster Than Expected
items.text:
Satellite radar caught them sinking. New York, Baltimore, Norfolk—major infrastructure dropping 1-2mm yearly since 2007. Some Delaware counties: three times faster. Water plants, rail lines, airports. All built for flood projections that no longer exist.

via The Docket
items.compliance_detail: ✓ Quote ratio, ✓ Verbatim overlap, ✓ Attribution, ✓ Claim density
items.compliance_original: Satellite radar caught them sinking. New York, Baltimore, Norfolk—major infrastructure dropping 1-2mm yearly since 2007. Some Delaware counties: three times faster. Water plants, rail lines, airports. All built for flood projections that no longer exist.

items.article_title: Atlantic Coast Cities Sinking Faster Than Expected
items.text: The radar satellites achieved 50-meter resolution. Thirteen years of data. More than half the infrastructure in Atlantic coast cities sits on land that's subsiding faster than anyone projected. JFK Airport. Rail networks. Water treatment facilities. All sinking beneath the flood maps they were designed for. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07038-3 #subsidence #climateinfrastructure

items.text:

Groundwater pumping compacts aquifers, causing more than half the region's measured sea level rise.
